text: Is there an intermediate between `@elapsed` (easy, fast, inaccurate) and `@belapsed` (slow, high overhead, accurate)? E.g. I was just timing something where `@belapsed myfun() seconds=2` took 16 seconds, which is enough to get bored staring at the terminal :confused: I want a macro which is sort of like `@belapsed_with_hard_time_limit myfun() hard_limit_seconds=2`, does that exist?

text: You can pass options to BenchmarkTools, or I think set them globally in your startup file

text: IIRC, BenchmarkTools does some tuning to make sure a run takes 5s (or the length of one run, if it's slower than that)

elements.text: IIRC, BenchmarkTools does some tuning to make sure a run takes 5s (or the length of one run, if it's slower than that)

text: I really wish there were some more output while this was happening though

elements.text: I really wish there were some more output while this was happening though

text: That would be nice to have, goes with the 1.6 theme…

elements.text: That would be nice to have, goes with the 1.6 theme…

text:
I am super not a BenchmarkTools expert but it seems like it does some setup, then runs your code in a loop until a set amount of time has elapsed (default 5 seconds). But if that setup is really slow, the whole `@belapsed`  can also be slow.

E.g. in my case `@belapsed myfun() seconds=2` took 16 seconds, but with `seconds=5` it took 19 seconds => suggest 14 seconds of setup overhead

@belapsed

E.g. in my case

took 16 seconds, but with

it took 19 seconds => suggest 14 seconds of setup overhead
yes, that's the tuning

text: the tuning is just running it a few times to get a feel for how long each run takes, how many evaluations per run should be done etc.

elements.text: the tuning is just running it a few times to get a feel for how long each run takes, how many evaluations per run should be done etc.
